Fig. 1 Influence of Ce/Ni molar ratio on o-xylene oxidation (a); effect of third metal addition on o-xylene oxidation (b); impact of Co/Ni molar ratio on o-xylene oxidation (c); influence of surfactant addition in catalyst preparation solution on o-xylene oxidation (d). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Effects of O2 concentration on o-xylene conversion (a), CO2 selectivity (b), and CO selectivity (c); effects of o-xylene concentration on o-xylene conversion (d), CO2 selectivity (e), and CO selectivity (f); effects of WHSV on o-xylene conversion (g), CO2 selectivity (h), and CO selectivity (i). Aromatic hydrocarbon volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from various emission sources are detrimental to environmental quality, human health, and ecosystems. This study developed a high-performance nickel foam (NF) monolithic catalyst, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, via hydrothermal synthesis to address the issues of agglomeration, poor stability, and moderate efficiency of traditional powdered catalysts. The catalyst was optimized with a Ce/Ni molar ratio of 0.23 and a Co/Ni molar ratio of 0.34. Adding polyethylene glycol 200 (PEG-200) as a morphology modifier further enhanced its performance and stability, increasing the specific surface area to 17.78 m2/g. Characterization revealed a stable honeycomb porous structure and unique morphology, with active substances uniformly dispersed on the NF surface, resulting in abundant oxygen vacancies and favorable redox properties. Operando DRIFTS experiments elucidated the reaction mechanism and adsorption behavior during o-xylene oxidation, highlighting the crucial role of active oxygen species and carbonate intermediates (M=O, monodentate, and bidentate carbonates) on the catalyst surface. This high-performance catalyst offers a novel approach for efficient VOCs catalytic oxidation, with significant practical and environmental implications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Monolithic catalyst Nickel foam Co3O4-CeO2 Morphology Operando DRIFTS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the atmosphere can cause serious environmental problems such as air pollution, ozone layer depletion, and the greenhouse effect [1–3], and lead to photochemical smog, impacting ecosystems and human health, and increasing the risk of respiratory diseases and cancer [4–6]. In response, many countries and regions, including China [4], the United States [5], the European Union [6], and Japan [7], have established strict VOC emission standards and regulations to reduce their potential harm to the environment and human health [8]. Among various VOCs, o-xylene is a typical pollutant. It mainly comes from fossil fuel combustion, waste incineration, and chemical industries such as petroleum processing, polymer or resin manufacturing, and semiconductor manufacturing [12–14]. Additionally, improper storage and handling of substances or raw materials containing o-xylene, like tank and transportation leaks, can also result in its emission [9]. Current VOCs treatment technologies include condensation, adsorption, absorption, membrane separation, incineration, catalytic oxidation, photocatalytic degradation, and plasma technology [10,11]. These technologies have limitations. Condensation and absorption efficiency are influenced by VOCs concentration. Adsorption is restricted by adsorbent limitations. Membrane separation is costly. However, catalytic oxidation, which completely degrades VOCs at low temperatures, is considered optimal [12], making suitable catalyst development crucial. Catalysts are mainly divided into noble-metal and transition-metal-oxide (TMO) types. Noble-metal catalysts are limited by scarcity and instability [13]. In contrast, TMO catalysts (e.g., oxides of Ce, Co, Mn, Fe, Cu, Ni) are ideal due to their low cost and stability [14]. Notably, CeO2 enhances catalyst performance due to its high oxygen storage and release capacity, suitable surface acid sites, and efficient Ce3+/Ce4+ conversion [15,16]. Jang et al. prepared a Ce-Mn homogeneous solid solution catalyst via redox co-precipitation [17]. Dong et al. used sol-gel and impregnation methods to make Ce-MnO2 composites [18]. The strong interaction between Ce and Mn species optimizes the catalyst's microstructure and surface properties. It refines grain size, increases specific surface area and oxygen vacancies, and enhances activity. Cobalt oxide (CoOx) is another key focus in catalyst research. Co-based catalysts lower the activation energy for reactions between VOCs and oxygen molecules, altering reaction pathways to reduce energy consumption [19]. Co3O4 nano-catalysts exhibit high aromatic hydrocarbon oxidation activity due to their high surface area, defective structure, abundant surface-adsorbed oxygen species, and numerous high-valent cobalt ions [20]. Moreover, CoOx catalysts can form composite materials with other metal oxides or non-metallic materials, where synergistic effects significantly boost catalytic performance [21]. The multiple valence states of cobalt ions (Co2+ and Co3+) allow CoOx to be categorized into CoO, Co2O3, and Co3O4. The catalytic oxidation performance of CoOx towards VOCs is mainly influenced by pollutant adsorption, catalyst activation, and C-H bond cleavage, all of which are closely related to the valence states of cobalt ions [22]. Catalysts with abundant Co3+ centers excel in aromatic hydrocarbon oxidation, even rivaling the most effective noble metal catalysts [23]. This enhanced catalytic activity is mainly attributed to Co3+ centers' activation of C-H bonds. Zhang et al. prepared spherical Mn-doped Co3O4 spinel catalysts via a solvothermal method, and found that the interaction between Co and Mn ions (Mn3+ + Co3+ → Mn4+ + Co2+) increased the catalyst's surface Co2+, Mn4+, and lattice oxygen content, significantly enhancing its activity, and the formation of Mn-O-Co bond on the spinel catalyst's surface improved surface oxygen mobility [24]. Nevertheless, the majority of the aforementioned catalysts exist in powder form, which is often associated with disadvantages like poor adaptability, a tendency to clog, and insufficient hydrothermal stability. These issues significantly hinder their practical industrial applications. Conversely, monolithic catalysts have emerged as a focal point of research. For example, three-dimensional metallic materials, including nickel foam, aluminum foam, iron foam, and stainless-steel mesh, can be utilized as supports for active components [25]. Among these materials, nickel foam stands out as a porous mesh carrier. It has high porosity, good mechanical strength, and high heat and mass transfer efficiency [32]. Its porous structure is great for loading active components and increasing active sites. Compared to copper and iron foam, nickel foam shows much better chemical stability. Under high-temperature and high-pressure conditions, copper and iron foam are easily damaged by oxidation and corrosion. However, nickel foam's surface forms a dense NiO film when oxidized, effectively protecting its own structure and properties. Moreover, when nickel foam is used as a carrier, NiO can work synergistically with surface-active components to enhance catalytic efficiency. To fully utilize these advantages, active components can be loaded using methods like impregnation, hydrothermal synthesis, sol-gel, deposition-precipitation, and quenching. In these methods, hydrothermal synthesis is frequently employed for in-situ growth. It enables the preparation of single crystals, thin films, and nanoparticles, thereby significantly enhancing the stability of active components on the support surface. During hydrothermal preparation, adding appropriate surfactants is sometimes beneficial. These surfactants not only have good adsorption capacity for active components, optimizing the physical properties of the catalyst and improving its stability and durability, but also alter the interfacial properties between the active components and support. For example, Zhan et al. prepared a nickel foam monolithic catalyst coated with defect-rich NiO film (NiO@NF) via oxalic acid-assisted hydrothermal synthesis for promoting ozonation [26]. They systematically investigated the mechanisms of NiO film formation and its catalytic performance. Zhang et al. hydrothermally grew Co-based oxides on nickel foam in situ. The resulting catalyst exhibited a unique hierarchical structure oriented at an angle or perpendicular to the Ni surface [24]. They explored that the morphology of the Co-based oxide catalyst on the nickel foam substrate mainly consisted of intercrossing curly nanosheets, nanowires, columnar nanoclusters, and coral-like microspheres. The Co3O4 nanoparticles supported on nickel foam demonstrated outstanding catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Previous reports have shown that polyethylene glycol 200 (PEG-200), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), and ammonium fluoride (NH4F) can effectively modulate the crystalline morphology of catalysts during their synthesis [27–30]. Although nickel foam monolithic catalysts have been extensively investigated for their role in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, there is a notable absence of reports on the catalytic oxidation of xylene-related VOCs. This research aims to develop a monolithic catalyst with a unique morphology and stable structure on nickel foam. The active components, CeO2 and Co3O4, are loaded via the hydrothermal method, with the addition of morphology modifiers to optimize the catalytic performance. The performance of the catalysts in o-xylene oxidation is evaluated using a thermal catalytic device. The kinetics of o-xylene oxidation and the stability of the catalysts are comprehensively assessed through various influential factors. The catalytic mechanism of o-xylene oxidation is elucidated through detailed catalyst characterization and operando diffuse reflectance Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) under specifically designed reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Pretreatment: The nickel foam (purchased from Guangjiayuan New Material, China, with a porosity of 130 pores per inch and a dimension of Φ10 × 4 mm2) was pretreated to remove surface impurities by washing with hydrochloric acid (4 mol/L), water, and ethanol, and dried at 80°C for 6 h. This pretreated nickel foam was defined as NF. Preparation of Ce/NF catalysts: CeO2 was loaded on the NF via a hydrothermal method. A series of catalysts with varying Ce/Ni molar ratios (0.10, 0.15, 0.19, 0.23, 0.27, and 0.31) were prepared and designated as Ce0.10/NF, Ce0.15/NF, Ce0.19/NF, Ce0.23/NF, Ce0.27/NF, and Ce0.31/NF, respectively. The detailed procedure for the preparation of Ce0.23/NF is given below as an example: 3.41 g of cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.5% purity, purchased from Aladdin, China) was first dissolved in 60 ml of deionized water, followed by the addition of 8 mmol of urea (99% purity, purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, China). The cerium nitrate/urea solution was subjected to magnetic stirring for 40 min. Then 2 g of NF discs were added into the solution. The solution of nitrate and urea was transferred into a stainless steel autoclave lined with polytetrafluoroethylene and placed in a hydrothermal reaction oven at 120°C for 12 h. After the hydrothermal reaction, the NF discs were washed with water, dried at 80°C for 6 h, and calcined at 550°C for 3 h to obtain the Ce0.23/NF catalyst. Preparation of M-Ce0.23/NF catalysts: Based on the optimal Ce/Ni molar ratio catalyst, the selection of the optimal third metal was further explored. The catalysts incorporating different third metals (M = Mn, Fe, Co, or Cu, from their nitrates all with 99% purity, purchased from Aladdin, China) were prepared with molar ratio of 0.23 for both M/Ni and Ce/Ni. The as-prepared catalysts were designated as Mn0.23-Ce0.23/NF, Fe0.23-Ce0.23/NF, Co0.23-Ce0.23/NF, and Cu0.23-Ce0.23/NF, respectively. The preparation procedure for each catalyst was analogous to that of Ce0.23/NF, with the exception that the nitrate of the third metal and cerium nitrate were used for hydrothermal reaction. Preparation of Co-Ce0.23/NF catalysts: Experimental evaluation identified Co as the optimal third metal for enhancing catalytic performance. Based on this finding, the molar ratio of Co/Ni was further optimized. A series of catalysts incorporating Co with varying Co/Ni molar ratios (0.17, 0.23, 0.28, 0.34, and 0.40) and Ce with a fixed Ce/Ni molar ratio of 0.23 were prepared using the same method as that employed for the Ce0.23/NF catalyst, with the exception of the amounts of cobalt and cerium nitrates used. The prepared catalysts were designated as Co0.17-Ce0.23/NF, Co0.23-Ce0.23/NF, Co0.28-Ce0.23/NF, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF, and Co0.40-Ce0.23/NF, respectively. Preparation of Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF catalysts with morphology modifiers: Three morphology modifiers, PEG-200, CTAB (99% purity), and ammonium fluoride (NH4F, 96% purity), were employed to modulate the crystalline morphology of cobalt and cerium oxides in the preparation of Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF catalysts. These modifiers were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, China. Each modifier, at a dosage of 4 mmol, was added to the mixture of cobalt nitrate and cerium nitrate (having molar ratios of Co/Ni = 0.34 and Ce/Ni = 0.23), urea, and NF discs prior to the hydrothermal reaction. The resulting catalysts were accordingly designated as Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-CTAB, and Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-NH4F, respectively. 2.2 Activity evaluation The activity evaluation was conducted for the optimization of catalyst component using a quartz tube reactor with a dimension of 10 × 12 × 370 mm3. The catalyst discs (1 g) were loaded in the center of the reactor and fed with a 100 ml/min gas mixture of 20% O2 balanced with N2, equaling a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 12000 ml/(g·h). Liquid o-xylene was vaporized into the gas mixture using a micro injector (TYD01-01, Baoding Lead Fluid Technology, China) to simulate a VOC containing gas with 200 ppm o-xylene. A gas chromatograph (GC-9790II, Fuli Instruments, China) was used to analyze the concentrations of o-xylene, CO, and CO2 in the gas mixtures at the inlet and outlet of the reactor. The effects of O2 concentration, o-xylene concentration, and WHSV on o-xylene oxidation at various temperatures were evaluated by systematically varying each parameter while keeping the others constant. The O2 concentration was tested at 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%, while o-xylene concentrations were varied at 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 ppm. Additionally, WHSV values were tested at 6000, 12000, 24000, 36000, and 48000 ml/(g·h). The stability performance was evaluated at 220°C with a WHSV of 12000 ml/(g·h), 20% O2, and 200 ppm o-xylene balanced with N2, and the reaction was sustained for 20 h. For the experiment evaluating the effect of H2O vapor on o-xylene oxidation, the reaction was initially conducted under the same conditions (220°C, WHSV of 12000 ml/(g·h), 20% O2, and 200 ppm o-xylene balanced with N2) for 1 h. Subsequently, water vapor was introduced into the gas stream at a concentration of 2% for an additional 2 h. Afterward, the H2O vapor was removed, and the reaction continued for another 1 h under the original conditions. By-products in the gas phase were collected during o-xylene oxidation at 170°C for 4 h by absorbing the effluent gas from the reactor with 5 ml of anhydrous ethanol, and the resulting ethanol liquid was analyzed using a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry system (GC-MS, 8860+5977B, Agilent, USA). By-products on the catalyst surface were obtained by washing the catalyst with 5 ml of anhydrous ethanol, and the obtained ethanol liquid was analyzed using the GC-MS. The conversion of o-xylene (X) and the selectivity to COx (SCOₓ, x=1 or 2) were calculated as follows: (1) X = 100 % × C i − C o C o (2) S C O x = 100 % × C C O x , o u t C i × 8 C i and C o represent the concentrations of o-xylene at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. C C O x , o u t represents the concentration of CO or CO2, or (CO+CO2) in the reactor's exhaust gas mixture. 2.3 Catalyst characterization A variety of techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts, detailed characterization procedures and methodological parameters are provided in the S1 of the Supplementary Information (SI). 2.4 Operando DRIFTS experiments o-Xylene-TPR-DRIFTS: The intermediates on the catalyst surface during o-xylene oxidation were analyzed using a DRIFTS (Nicolet IS50, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with an operando unit (Harrick, USA). The unit filled with the catalyst powder was pretreated at 300°C for 40 min under an Ar flow (20 ml/min), cooled to room temperature and stabilized for 30 min, then the background spectrum was collected. Subsequently, the Ar gas was switched to a gas with 200 ppm o-xylene in 20% O2 balanced with Ar at a total gas flow rate of 20 ml/min. The temperature of the unit was then heated to 400°C with a ramp of 10 °C/min. During the heating period, the spectra were collected every 50°C. Pulse-DRIFTS: The experiments were carried out to investigate the behaviors of o-xylene, O2 and H2O on the catalyst. The catalyst-filled unit was pretreated at 300°C for 40 min under an Ar flow of 20 ml/min, cooled to 205 °C and stabilized for 30 min, then the background spectrum was collected. For the o-xylene pulse DRIFTS experiment, Ar gas (20 ml/min) was supplied for 30 min, then switched to a gas mixture of 200 ppm o-xylene balanced with Ar (20 ml/min). This gas switching process was repeated one more time. Spectra were collected every 10 min. For the O2-pulse DRIFTS experiment, the gas mixture used was 20% O2 balanced with Ar instead of o-xylene. Similarly, for the H2O-pulse DRIFTS experiment, the gas mixture was 1% H2O balanced with Ar instead of 200 ppm o-xylene in Ar. All collected spectra were converted into absorption/desorption spectra using the Kubelka-Munk function. For comparison, the heights of targeted peaks were normalized [31]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of catalyst’s component The Ce/Ni molar ratio was initially optimized by evaluating the performance of o-xylene oxidation on the catalysts with various Ce/Ni ratios, with the results shown in Fig. 1 a. Below 250°C, the catalyst with a Ce/Ni ratio of 0.31 exhibited the highest o-xylene conversion. However, above 250°C, the catalyst with a Ce/Ni ratio of 0.23 demonstrated superior performance. Given the preference for lower Ce content, Ce0.23/NF was selected for further screening of the third metal. Fig. 1b illustrates the relationship between o-xylene conversion and reaction temperature after the addition of equimolar amounts of a third metal. The T50 value (the temperature at which o-xylene conversion was 50%) was used to precisely compare the performance of each catalyst. The T50 value for Ce0.23/NF was 241°C, while the lowest T50 value after adding the third metal was 192°C (Co0.23-Ce0.23/NF), a significant difference of 49°C. This indicates that the introduction of a third metal could substantially enhance o-xylene conversion. Subsequently, the dosage of Co was optimized. With the Ce/Ni ratio fixed at 0.23, the Co/Ni molar ratio was varied between 0.17 and 0.40 to observe the o-xylene conversion. As shown in Fig. 1c, the catalyst with a Co/Ni ratio of 0.34 (Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF) exhibited the lowest T50 value of 180°C, which was 32°C lower than that of the catalyst with the highest T50 value (Co0.17-Ce0.23/NF). This demonstrates that optimizing the Co dosage also significantly improved the oxidation of o-xylene. Finally, three morphology modifiers were employed to enhance the performance of the catalysts, with the results depicted in Fig. 1d. The results clearly showed that the o-xylene conversion was higher for the Co0.34–Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst prepared with PEG-200 compared to that without a modifier, with the T50 value reduced to 170°C. The results indicate that incorporating PEG-200 enhanced catalytic activity, whereas NH4F and CTAB led to less active catalysts, suggesting a negative impact from these two modifiers. This difference was likely attributed to the increased surface area provided by PEG-200, as detailed later. 3.2 Evaluation of the optimized catalyst 3.2.1 Catalyst performance The catalytic performance of Co0.34–Ce0.23/NF-PEG was systematically evaluated against previously reported monolithic catalysts that do not incorporate Pt or Pd (Fig. S1 and Table S1). At an o-xylene concentration of 200 ppm and a WHSV of 12000 ml/(g·h), a turnover frequency (TOF) of 0.468 mmol/g/h was achieved with complete conversion already below 215°C. Under these conditions, Co0.34–Ce0.23/NF-PEG exhibits markedly lower light-off temperatures than comparable monolithic catalysts exhibiting similar TOFs. When the WHSV was increased to 48000 ml/(g·h) while maintaining the o-xylene feed at 200 ppm, the TOF rose to 1.52 mmol/g/h; at equivalent reaction temperatures, this value substantially exceeded those reported for other monolithic catalysts. 3.2.2 Assessment of factor’s influence on catalyst performance The study also delved into the catalysts' performance, factoring in O2 concentration, o-xylene concentration, and WHSV. With O2 concentration as the variable (Figs. 2 a-c), o-xylene conversion was found to rise with increasing O2 concentrations. At 20% O2 concentration, o-xylene conversion was 90% at 205°C, a 4.8% improvement over the 10% O2 concentration condition. This finding could stem from a higher O2 concentration boosts o-xylene oxidation [32]. When o-xylene concentration was the focus (Figs. 2d-f), performance declined with higher o-xylene concentrations, alongside a drop in CO2 selectivity. Increased o-xylene concentration resulted in more o-xylene molecules entering the reactor per unit time, while the catalyst's active sites remained constant. This reduced the interaction chances between each molecule and the active sites, lowering catalytic efficiency. With WHSV as the variable (Figs. 2g-i), both catalyst performance and CO2 selectivity decreased as WHSV rose at the three temperatures. Higher WHSV shortened the gas residence time in the reactor, reducing contact time between pollutant molecules and the catalyst surface, and leading to incomplete reactions [33,34]. Based on the experimental outcomes of factor’s influence, the kinetic equation for the catalytic oxidation of o-xylene and the activation energy were successfully determined. A comprehensive description could be found in the S2 of the SI. 3.2.3 Assessment of stability and waterproof performance Fig. 3 a illustrates a subsequent 20-h stability evaluation of the o-xylene oxidation on the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst. During the evaluation period, o-xylene conversion revealed only a 2.4% decline, indicating relatively stable catalyst activity with no significant deactivation. Under the aforementioned stability experimental conditions, a 240-min experiment introducing 2% H2O vapor was conducted (Fig. 3b). Without H2O vapor the in first 60 min, the o-xylene conversion remained at 100%. From 60 to 180 min, with 2% H2O vapor introduced, the o-xylene conversion dropped to 92.65% (a 7.13% decrease), suggesting water's inhibitory effect on the o-xylene oxidation, likely due to H2O molecules competing with O2 or active sites for adsorption and reducing catalytic efficiency [35]. Furthermore, subsequent H2O-pulse DRIFTS experiments revealed that H2O could react with surface oxygen to form -OH groups, which impeded the decomposition of O2 on the catalyst surface. After discontinuing H2O vapor at 180 min, the catalyst's activity recovered, implying no destructive impact of H2O on the catalyst itself or its physicochemical properties. This stability was probably due to the inherent stability of the NF monolithic catalyst's metallic framework and the secure adsorption of active substances [36–39]. 3.2.4 By-products in the exhaust and on the catalyst During the optimization of the aforementioned catalysts, it was observed that achieving 100% conversion did not correspond to equivalent selectivity. This indicated some pollutants transformed into by-products during the experiment. GC-MS analyzed the exhaust gases from Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, Ce0.23/NF, and Co0. 34/NF, as shown in Fig. 3c. The main peaks were assigned to benzene, toluene, and o-xylene, with peak intensities inversely related to the catalytic performance: better performance correlated with lower peak intensity. The gas-phase detection results of the surface compounds, displayed in Fig. 3d, included isopropanol, benzyl alcohol, and o-xylene. The presence of xylene on the catalyst surface indicates that o-xylene can be adsorbed onto the catalyst [40]. The detection of benzene and toluene on the catalyst surface suggests that o-xylene had undergone demethylation [35]. The presence of benzyl alcohol in the gas phase indicated partial oxidation of the methyl groups in o-xylene [41]. The formation of isopropanol, which requires ring-opening and subsequent oxidation of the benzene ring, demonstrates that o-xylene oxidation involved a ring-opening process and that the oxidation was not complete, as not all products were fully oxidized to CO2. From the above analysis, it could be concluded that the selectivity towards COx (CO and CO2) did not reach 100% because a portion of the o-xylene was converted into benzyl alcohol and isopropanol. 3.3 Catalyst characterization 3.3.1 Structural and morphological analyses of the catalysts Fig. S2 presents the XRD analysis of Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, Ce0.23/NF, Co0. 34/NF, and NF. The diffraction peaks at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.3° were attributed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of CeO2, respectively [42]. The peaks at 36.7° and 65.2° corresponded to the (511) and (440) planes of Co3O4. These characteristic peaks coexisted with those of NF (nickel metal) at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4°, which were assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni [43,44]. Their presence on the monolithic catalyst Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG indicates that cerium and cobalt oxides had been successfully loaded onto the NF. SEM was used to investigate the morphological characteristics of the monolithic catalysts, as shown in Figs. 4 a-f. The catalysts supported on the NF framework exhibited a highly stable honeycomb porous structure [27]. Under hydrothermal reaction conditions, the active components formed distinct morphologies on the metallic framework. For instance, in Figs. 4b and c, CeO2 existed as particles attached to the three-dimensional framework, while Co3O4 formed cluster-like sea urchin shapes. The effect of three morphology modifiers on the catalysts was compared, as shown in Figs. S3a-l and Figs. 4d-e. For Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF without a modifier, the loading of active components was low [45], with capillary-like long fibers covering the surface, deviating from the single-component morphology. This might result from interactions between active components. For Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-CTAB, active component loading was higher, with CeO2 forming spindle-shaped rods and Co3O4 losing its fibrous sea urchin shape, possibly due to excessive accumulation or morphological changes in Co3O4, reducing catalytic activity. Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-NH4F had the lowest active component loading and a disordered microstructure, corresponding to the lowest catalytic activity. In contrast, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG exhibited the highest catalytic activity, successfully growing active substances on the NF framework and maintaining the fibrous and sea urchin-like morphology of cobalt oxide, with cerium oxide rods interspersed for a uniform and stable structure. SEM-EDS mapping images of Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG (Figs. 4g-j) revealed a uniform distribution of elements, effectively modulating the catalyst surface's electronic structure to provide more active sites. This enhanced reactant interaction and catalytic efficiency while reducing active substance accumulation, increasing the specific surface area, and avoiding potential catalyst poisoning. Fig. 5 shows the HRTEM images of three catalysts, clearly revealing their lattice structures. The lattice fringes of 0.316 and 0.172 nm in Fig. 5d corresponded to CeO2's (111) and (311) planes [46], respectively. The 0.153 nm fringe in Fig. 5e matched Co3O4's (511) plane [47], while the 0.330 nm fringe in Fig. 5f corresponded to CeO2's (111) plane. These findings aligned with the subsequent XRD results. Moreover, the HRTEM images showed overlapping and combined interfaces within the catalysts. For example, the CeO2 (111) plane's lattice spacing of 0.330 nm exhibited evident distortion and expansion compared to the 0.316 nm spacing above it. This interfacial effect changed the atomic coordination environment and bond lengths, modulated the catalyst's electronic structure. It significantly enhanced the combination of the two elements, strengthens their synergistic effects, and improved their adsorption and activation capabilities. 3.3.2 Surface analysis As depicted in Figs. S4 a-d and Figs. S5a-c, all catalysts displayed classic Type IV isotherms [48]. Table 1 summarizes their specific surface areas, pore volumes, and pore sizes. The specific surface area followed the order: Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG > Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF > Ce0.23/NF > Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-CTAB > Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-NH4F > Co0. 34/NF > NF. Notably, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG boasts the highest specific surface area at 17.8 m2/g. The data indicates that adding PEG-200 markedly increased the monolithic catalysts' specific surface area. A larger specific surface area means more active sites on the catalyst surface, which are vital for reactant molecule adsorption and chemical reactions. Thus, a higher specific surface area of the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst allowed more reactant molecules to interact with the catalyst surface simultaneously, greatly boosting the catalytic reaction rate [49,50]. Fig. 6 a presents the Raman spectra of the catalysts, offering insights into their crystal structures and bonding environments. The Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst showed CeO2-related F2TA and F2g peaks at 222 and 466 cm–1. The F2g peak indicated a fluorite CeO2 structure, while the F2TA peak suggested oxygen vacancies or anionic defects within this structure [51]. Co3O4's F2g and A1g peaks appeared at 189 and 668 cm–1 in Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, with enhanced widths and intensities, confirming the presence of Co3O4 spinel. The interaction between the components caused these peaks to shift to higher wavenumbers (blue shift), implying lattice distortion or strain, which created defects beneficial for oxygen vacancy formation and enhanced o-xylene oxidation [52]. EPR analysis was performed on Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG to further investigate oxygen vacancies, as shown in Fig. 6b. All five catalysts exhibited a distinct oxygen vacancy signal at g = 2.003, with concentrations ordered as Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG > Co0.40-Ce0.23/NF-PEG > Co0.17-Ce0.23/NF-PEG > Ce0.23/NF > Co0. 34/NF. These results aligned with XPS findings, indicating that Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG had the highest oxygen vacancy concentration. This high concentration enhanced lattice oxygen adsorption and mobility, improved the catalyst's redox capability towards o-xylene oxidation [53–55]. XPS analysis is a powerful tool for probing the chemical transformations on material surfaces post-modification, offering detailed insights into the electronic structure and valence states of the surface. As depicted in Fig. S6, the Ni 2p spectrum revealed satellite peaks at 854.8 and 872.0 eV, alongside the characteristic peaks of Ni2+ at 862.4 and 887.1 eV [56,57]. These findings strongly suggest the presence of NiO on the catalyst surface, which was likely formed during the calcination of the NF substrate. The formation of a thin NiO layer on the surface effectively modified the inherently smooth surface of nickel foam. When used in conjunction with solution modifier, it significantly enhanced the specific surface area of the catalyst and facilitated a greater loading of active substances such as CeO2 and Co3O4. Beyond its role as a surface modifier, NiO also functioned as an active component of the catalyst. It provided active sites that facilitated the adsorption of reactant molecules and reduced the activation energy of the reaction, thereby enhanced the overall efficiency of the catalytic process [27]. In the Ce 3d spectrum shown in Fig. S6b, eight peaks were deconvoluted. Among them, the peaks at v0 (882.3 eV), v2 (888.6 eV), u3 (897.7 eV), u0 (903.7 eV), u2 (908.3 eV), and u3 (916.4 eV) were attributed to Ce4+, while the peaks at v1 (886.4 eV) and u1 (901.9 eV) were assigned to Ce3+ [58,59]. The presence of Ce3+ is typically used as an indicator of oxygen vacancies. The existence of Ce3+ ions introduced an imbalance of charge, which promoted the adsorption of oxygen on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the detection of Ce3+ ions indicated the presence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [60]. The Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst had the highest proportion of Ce3+, which was 21.4% as shown in Table 2 . The Co 2p spectrum of each catalyst was deconvoluted into six peaks as shown in Fig. S6c. Excluding the two satellite peaks at 787.4 and 803.3 eV, we focused on the analysis of the main cobalt peaks. The peaks at 781.4 and 796.6 eV were attributed to Co2+, while the peaks at 779.3 and 794.2 eV corresponded to Co3+ [61]. As shown in Table 2, for the optimal catalyst Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, the proportion of Co3+ in the total cobalt ions, Co3+/(Co2+ + Co3+), was 38.9%. This indicates that the catalyst had an optimal number of oxygen vacancies and good redox properties [62]. The O1s spectra deconvoluted into three peaks corresponding to different oxygen species are depicted in Fig. S6d: surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) at 529.3 eV, surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) at 531.0 eV, and surface adsorbed hydroxyl group (OOH) at 532.8 eV. The ratio of adsorbed oxygen (Oads) to the total oxygen species, Oads/(Oads + OOH + Olatt) is listed in Table 2. The Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst had the highest proportion of surface adsorbed oxygen. Olatt was embedded within the catalyst's crystal structure, forming stable chemical bonds with other components. In contrast, Oads resided on the catalyst surface and was relatively dynamic. Olatt participation in reactions required significant structural changes and energy overcoming energy barriers, unlike Oads, which interacted directly with reactant molecules on the surface [63]. During reactions, Oads contacted o-xylene molecules, breaking the C-H bonds in their methyl groups to form active intermediates. It also destabilized the benzene ring, lowering activation energy for subsequent steps, thereby reducing the reaction energy barrier and improving the catalytic activity of the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst. 3.3.3 Redox properties The redox properties were examined using H2-TPR and O2-TPD analyses. H2-TPR analysis was conducted to evaluate the reducibility of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 a, Ce0.23/NF exhibited a reduction peak at 335°C, corresponding to Ce4+ reduction to Ce3+. Co0. 34/NF showed two peaks at 346 and 291°C, attributed to Co3+ reduction to Co2+ and then to metallic Co. In contrast, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG's reduction peaks shifted to lower temperatures, indicating enhanced low-temperature reducibility. This improvement could alter the catalyst's surface properties, such as acidity, thereby boosting its ability to adsorb and activate reactants [64,65]. It also facilitated oxygen vacancy formation, which significantly enhanced the monolithic catalyst's degradation capability in o-xylene oxidation. Thus, the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst demonstrated superior low-temperature reducibility compared to Ce0.23/NF and Co0.34/NF due to the synergistic effects of its active metal components [66]. The formation and replenishment of oxygen vacancies are vital for maintaining catalyst activity and stability. Therefore, O2-TPD was used to investigate these mechanisms on the catalyst surface, with the results shown in Fig. 7b. Desorption peaks below 300°C indicated adsorbed oxygen (Oads), while those above 300°C corresponded to lattice oxygen (Olatt) [67,68]. The interaction between CeO2 and Co3O4 on the NF caused the Oads desorption peak to shift to lower temperatures and increased its peak area. Additionally, a significant Olatt adsorption peak appeared at 735°C, indicating that Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG retained the high Olatt mobility characteristic of Co0.34/NF. Consequently, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG had more oxygen vacancies and superior oxygen storage capacity. This enabled substantial surface-adsorbed oxygen desorption, reflecting significant active oxygen species migration and further enhancing the monolithic catalyst's activity [69,70]. 3.4 Investigation of the reaction mechanism 3.4.1 o-Xylene-TPR-DRIFTS experiments Operando DRIFTS experiments were conducted to analyze surface intermediates and gaseous products during temperature-programmed experiments. As shown in Fig. S8, peaks at 1300 cm–1 corresponded to terminal-type oxygen (M=O) [71], at 1583 cm–1 to monodentate carbonates [72], and at 1673 cm–1 to bidentate carbonates [73]. By-products like benzaldehyde (1073 cm–1) [74], benzoic acid (1673 cm–1) [75], and benzyl alcohol (1225 cm– 1) [76] were also identified, along with the bridged carboxyl group (-COOH) at 1358 cm–1 [74,75] and bridge-type oxygen M-O-M at 850 cm–1 [77]. The main products were normalized, with Figs. 8 a-c depicting intermediate products benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, and benzyl alcohol, respectively. Benzaldehyde was formed when the C-H bond of a methyl group combined with hydroxyl radicals (-OH) or lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface, resulting in the formation of an aldehyde group. Benzyl alcohol, an early-stage oxidation intermediate, could further oxidize to benzoic acid or volatilize. Benzoic acid resulted from the catalyst surface's active oxygen further oxidizing the aldehyde group to a carboxyl group [76], directly reflecting catalyst activity. As shown in the Fig. 10d, the highly active Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst exhibited the highest accumulation performance of the bridged carboxyl group (-COOH). The carboxyl group's appearance signified extensive oxidation, where the methyl side chain fully oxidized. This process involved the methyl group (-CH3) initially oxidizing to an alcohol (-CH2OH), then to an aldehyde (-CHO), and finally to a carboxylic acid (-COOH), confirming the formation of the three aforementioned by-products. Fig. 10e illustrates monodentate carbonate formation during catalysis. The three bimetallic monolithic catalysts with different molar ratios formed monodentate carbonates much faster than others, with Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG showing distinct characteristics below 100°C. Monodentate carbonate formation was linked to the catalyst surface's basic sites, which were more flexible and could rapidly convert and accumulate o-xylene during oxidation on highly active catalysts. Fig. 10f shows bidentate carbonate formation by the catalysts. Bimetallic monolithic catalysts exhibited stronger oxidation capabilities than monometallic ones, with all except Ce0.23/NF showing good low-temperature oxidation performance. Fig. 10g reveals the participation of surface oxygen species (M=O) in o-xylene oxidation. M=O consumption and dissociation increased with temperature, with Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG showing the fastest dissociation rate. This rapid M=O consumption could more effectively activate the oxidation of o-xylene. 3.4.2 o-Xylene-pulse DRIFTS experiments The operando DRIFTS experiments with pulsed adsorption were conducted to investigate the adsorption characteristics of o-xylene on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. S9, the experimental results revealed an adsorption peak for the C-H bond of o-xylene at 3267 cm–1 [75,78], indicating that o-xylene molecules were adsorbed onto the catalyst surface via C-H bond interactions. Characteristic peaks for monodentate carbonate (m-CO3 2–) and bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2–) were observed at 1673 and 1583 cm–1, respectively. By analyzing the normalized relative intensities of these peaks, insights into the catalyst's adsorption and oxidation behavior toward o-xylene were obtained. Initially, o-xylene was introduced between 30 and 60 min, leading to significant accumulation of the C-H bond of o-xylene. From 60 to 90 min, the introduction of o-xylene was halted, resulting in a decrease in relative peak heights due to partial oxidation. When o-xylene were reintroduced, the peak heights exceeded previous levels. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the C-H bond adsorption peak reflected the catalyst's ability to adsorb o-xylene molecules. A stronger C-H bond adsorption peak indicated a higher number of active sites on the catalyst surface, enabling effective adsorption of o-xylene molecules. The activation of C-H bonds by the active sites on the catalyst surface reduced the reaction activation energy and accelerates the reaction rate. The Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst combined the advantages of Ce0.23/NF and Co0. 34/NF catalysts. Due to the presence of Ce3+ and Co3+ active sites on its surface, it effectively activated C-H bonds, thereby promoting the oxidation of o-xylene. The Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst, with its active sites and abundant oxygen vacancies, efficiently adsorbed and activated C-H bonds, leading to the formation of significant amounts of monodentate and bidentate carbonates. A higher relative peak height of monodentate carbonate indicated a greater number of basic sites and active sites on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 9b, during the initial introduction of o-xylene, the relative peak heights of monodentate carbonates followed the order: Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG > Co0. 34/NF > Ce0.23/NF. During the second introduction of o-xylene, the relative peak height of Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG increased much more rapidly than those of other catalysts, indicating that monodentate carbonate was more sensitive to changes in o-xylene during adsorption and oxidation processes. As shown in Fig. 9c, bidentate carbonate was more sensitive to o-xylene introduction than monodentate carbonate. Co0. 34/NF exhibited a higher relative peak height during the first o-xylene introduction, but during the second introduction, it was surpassed by Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG. This demonstrates that Co3O4 had a stronger adsorption and oxidation capacity than CeO2, an advantage that was inherited by Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG. Therefore, the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst, with its abundant oxygen vacancies and active sites, rapidly adsorbed o-xylene during o-xylene oxidation. The active species reacted with o-xylene molecules to form intermediates (carbonates) more quickly and stably, thereby accelerating the oxidation of o-xylene. 3.4.3 O2-pulse DRIFTS experiments To explore the active oxygen sites on the catalyst, operando DRIFTS experiments with oxygen pulses were performed. As shown in Fig. S10, the peak at 1300 cm⁻1 corresponded to M=O, around 1100 cm–1 to superoxide species (M+-O2 –), around 980 cm⁻¹ to peroxide species (M2+=O2 2–), and around 820 cm–1 to M-O-M. Under O2 introduction, M=O, M+-O2 –, and M-O-M exhibited consumption and oxidation trends, which ceased and gradually recovered upon stopping oxygen supply. In contrast, peroxide species (M2+=O2 2–) showed an initial increase in relative peak height during oxygen introduction, slowing down upon oxygen cessation. From Figs. 10 a-c, after normalization, the consumption rates of M=O and M-O-M were relatively faster on the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG monolithic catalyst, indicating its higher oxygen vacancy concentration, beneficial for oxygen species activation and oxidation [79]. In Fig. 10d, M2+=O2 2– exhibited an accumulation phenomenon, contrary to the consumption of other oxygen species. This was because M2+=O2 2– filled oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface and interacted with metal ions to form active sites for pollutant adsorption and oxidation. 3.4.4 H2O-pulse DRIFTS experiments To investigate the impact of H2O on the catalyst, operando DRIFTS experiments with H2O pulses were conducted. As shown in Figs. S11a-d, the peak at 3644 cm–1 corresponded to the -OH group, 1625 cm–1 to H2O, 1300 cm–1 to the M=O species, 1070 cm–1 to the M⁺-O2 – species, 980 cm–1 to the M2+=O2 2– species, and 820 cm–1 to the M-O-M species. After water introduction, -OH and H2O peaks appeared, indicating that the catalyst surface's active sites allowed water molecule adsorption, competing with oxygen species [35]. Consequently, peaks for oxygen species like M=O and M+-O2 – decreased, while the -OH peak increased, showing that H2O molecules interacted with the catalyst surface, consuming oxygen species and forming hydroxyl group (Figs. 11 a-b). Compared to Co0. 34/NF, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG appeared less affected by H2O, but there was still a noticeable decline in catalyst performance. Upon stopping H2O supply, peaks corresponding to H2O and -OH gradually diminished, indicating water molecule desorption from the catalyst surface. Although the relative peaks appeared somewhat disordered, oxygen species peaks gradually recovered, suggesting partial reversion of the catalyst surface to its initial state. This incomplete recovery might be due to the duration following water supply cessation, as H2O molecules likely remained on the catalyst surface, occupying oxygen vacancies [35]. This phenomenon could be attributed to the monolithic catalyst's more stable metallic framework. Following the modifier addition, this catalyst's unique morphology, compared to others, endowed it with a more robust surface structure and enhanced chemical stability. Despite oxygen vacancy occupation, the system could nearly return to its initial state following desorption upon stopping the water supply. 3.4.5 Mechanistic insights into the catalytic oxidation of o-xylene Based on the results of various characterizations, the mechanism of o-xylene on the Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG catalyst was proposed in Fig. 12 . o-Xylene undergoes demethylation to form products such as toluene and benzene. Subsequently, intermediate products such as benzyl alcohol, 1,2-benzenediol, benzaldehyde, and benzoic acid are generated from their oxidation by reactive oxygen species [40] ([O], such as M=O and M-O-M). The reactive oxygen species are released from CeO2 and Co3O4 in the catalyst with the simultaneous formation of oxygen vacancies (M=□ and M-□-M, □ denotes oxygen vacancy). Benzyl alcohol is then oxidized to benzoic acid. The benzoic acid is further oxidized to maleic acid and partially to short-chain acids (formic acid and acetic acid) via ring open reactions [41]. Ultimately, these compounds are completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusion This study developed a honeycomb monolithic catalyst loaded with CeO2 and Co3O4 on nickel foam (NF) via hydrothermal synthesis and investigated its catalytic performance and reaction mechanism. (1) The optimal catalyst was achieved when the Ce/Ni molar ratio was 0.23 and the Co/Ni ratio was 0.34, with the addition of PEG-200 as the morphology modifier. This catalyst, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, reached 90% conversion at 205°C with a COx selectivity of 80.3%. (2) Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG featured a stable honeycomb structure and unique morphology, with CeO2 and Co3O4 uniformly dispersed on the NF surface. It had a larger specific surface area, higher oxygen vacancy concentration, and greater proportions of Ce3+ and Co3+ compared to other catalysts, indicating abundant active sites and strong redox properties. (3) Operando DRIFTS experiments elucidated the formation and consumption patterns of surface oxygen species, carbonates, and intermediates during o-xylene oxidation. Adsorption experiments revealed the catalyst's surface adsorption characteristics for H2O and O2. H2O/O2-pulse experiments showed that water molecules competed with oxygen species for active sites, forming hydroxyl group and reducing catalytic performance, although the effect on Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG was relatively small. The developed nickel honeycomb monolithic catalyst had excellent selectivity and water resistance, effectively treating harmful substances in industrial waste gases. Its good environmental adaptability and stability could make it suitable for various industrial emission scenarios. This study addressed the limitations of traditional catalysts in industrial applications by offering a new approach for efficient VOC catalytic oxidation. This approach is significant importance for environmental protection and sustainable development. coredata.dc:description: Aromatic hydrocarbon volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from various emission sources are detrimental to environmental quality, human health, and ecosystems. This study developed a high-performance nickel foam (NF) monolithic catalyst, Co0.34-Ce0.23/NF-PEG, via hydrothermal synthesis to address the issues of agglomeration, poor stability, and moderate efficiency of traditional powdered catalysts. The catalyst was optimized with a Ce/Ni molar ratio of 0.23 and a Co/Ni molar ratio of 0.34. Adding polyethylene glycol 200 (PEG-200) as a morphology modifier further enhanced its performance and stability, increasing the specific surface area to 17.78 m2/g. Characterization revealed a stable honeycomb porous structure and unique morphology, with active substances uniformly dispersed on the NF surface, resulting in abundant oxygen vacancies and favorable redox properties. Operando DRIFTS experiments elucidated the reaction mechanism and adsorption behavior during o-xylene oxidation, highlighting the crucial role of active oxygen species and carbonate intermediates (M=O, monodentate, and bidentate carbonates) on the catalyst surface. This high-performance catalyst offers a novel approach for efficient VOCs catalytic oxidation, with significant practical and environmental implications.
